dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A bunch of SOLDIERS are lined up at attention. LIEUTENANT ALDO.RAINE, a hillbilly from the mountains of Tennessee, walks down the line. He recruits the men, the Germans will later call; "The Basterds". Lt.Aldo has one defining physical characteristic, a ROPE BURN around his neck. As if once upon a time,. he survived a LYNCHING. The scar will never once be mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: My name is Lt.Aldo Raine, and I'm puttin together a special team. And I need me eight soldiers. Eight - Jewish - American - soldiers. Now y'all might of heard rumors about the armada happening soon. Well, we'll be leavin a little earlier. We're gonna be dropped into France, dressed as civilians. And once we're in enemy territory, as a bushwackin, guerrilla army, we're gonna be doin one thing, and thing only, Killin Nazi's. The Members of the National Socialist Party, have conquered Europe through murder, torture, intimidation, and terror. And that's exactly what we're gonna do to them. Now I don't know bout y'all? But I sure as hell, didnt come down from the goddamn Smoky mountains, cross five thousand miles of water, fight my way through half Sicily, and then jump out of a fuckin air-o-plane, to teach the Nazi's lessons in humanity. Nazi ain't got no humanity. There the foot soldiers of a Jew hatin, mass murderin manic, and they need to be destroyed. That's why any and every son-of-a--bitch we find wearin a Nazi uniform, there gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: if.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will be cruel to the Germans, and through our cruelty, they will know who we are. They will find the evidence of our cruelty, in the disembowed, dismembered, and disfigured bodies of their brothers we leave behind us. And the German will not be able to help themselves from imagining the cruelty their brothers endured at our hands, and our boot heels, and the edge of our knives. And the Germans, will be sickened by us. And the Germans, will talk about us. And the Germans, will fear us. And when the Germans close their eyes at night, and their sub conscious tortures them for the evil they've done, it will be with thoughts of us, that it tortures them with. He stops pacing, and looks at everybody.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: Sound good? They all say;

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: That's what I like to hear. But I got a word of warning to all would-be warriors. When you join my command, you take on debit. A debit you owe me, personally. Every man under my command, owes me, one hundred nazi scalps. And I want my scalps. And all y'all will git me, one hundred Nazi scalps, taken from the heads of one hundred dead Nazi's... .or you will die trying.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A huge Chalet on a misty mountain top in Barvia.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In a huge room, ADOLPH HITLER, pounds on a big table with his fist, as he rants at TWO GERMAN GENERALS. They speak GERMAN SUBTITLED into ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: How much more of these jew swine must I endure? They butcher my men like they were fish bait! This pack of filthy degenerates, are doing what the Russian army didn't, and Patton's army couldn't. Turning soldiers of The Third Reich, into superstitious old women!

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Just the cowards among them mine Fuhrer. Hitler pounds furiously on the desk with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no, no! I have heard the rumors myself! Solders of The Third Reich, who have brought the world to there knee`s, now pecking and clucking like chickens. Do you know the latest rumor they've conjured up, in their fear induced delirium? The one that beats my boys with a bat. The one they call "The Bear Jew"...is a Golem. A avenging jew angel, conjured up by a vengeful rabbi, to smite the Aryans!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Mine Fuhrer, this is just soldiers gossip, no one really believes The Bear Jew is a golem.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Why not? They seem to be able to elude capture like a aberration. They seem to be able to appear and disappear at will.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to prove their flesh and blood? Then BRING THEM TO ME! I will hang them naked, by their heels, from the eiffel tower! And then throw their bodies in the sewers, for the rats of Paris to feast! The Fuhrer sits down at the table to compose himself, and wipe his greasy black hair out of his face.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: (DISGUSTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bear Jew. He hits the button on the intercom on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: KLIEST1
dialogues.text: KLIEST VOICE comes out of the intercom;

dialogues.speaker: KLIEST'S VOICE, (OS)
dialogues.text: Year mine Fuhrer.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: I have a order I want relayed to all German soldiers stationed in France. The Jew degenerate known as The Bear Jew, hence forth, is never to be referred to as The Bear Jew again. We will cease to aid the Americans any longer in there attempt to undermine the German soldier psyche. Did you get that Kliest?

dialogues.speaker: KLIEST'S VOICE, (OS)
dialogues.text: Yes mine Fubrer. Do you still wish to see Private Butz?

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Who and what is a private Butz?

dialogues.speaker: KELIST'S VOICE, (OS)
dialogues.text: He's the soldier you wanted to see personally. His squad was ambushed by Lt.Raines Jews. He was it's only survivor.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Indeed I do want to see him, thank you for reminding me. Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: CU FACE OF DEAD GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: His head lies on the ground horizontal. A HAND reaches in FRAME, KNOCKS aside the dead German patriots helmet, and grabs a handful of the cadavers blonde hair. A LARGE KNIF ENTERS FRAME, and begins SLICING ALONG THE HAIRLINE. This process is called SCALPING. After SLICING is complete, the SCALP easily peels off lik banana.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN PRISONERS PVT.BUTZ AND SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: on their knees, hands behind there heads. Private Butz NARRATES the scene in GERMAN SUBTITLED into ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: Werner and I were the only ones left alive after the ambush. While one man guarded us, the rest removed the hair. All The Basterds wore German scalps tied to their belts.

dialogues.speaker: CU SCALPS
dialogues.text: hanging from belts.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: They not only took valuables...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rings, Weapons, Iron Cross, and somebody digging out a Go Tooth with a knife, being removed from Dead Germans.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: ..They also took their identification papers.

dialogues.speaker: CU IDENTIFICATION PAPERS
dialogues.text: taken from the inside pocket of a dead German uniform.

dialogues.speaker: BASTERD PFC.UTIVICH
dialogues.text: flips through the I.D. papers till he gets to the page th contains the German soldiers, name, statistics, and photo

dialogues.speaker: PFC.UTIVICH
dialogues.text: Sigfried Muller.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: .and tore out the identification page. Utivich RIPS the page out, and sticks it in his pocket. Tossing the torn book on the dead, scalpless body.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: ...They then removed their boots...

dialogues.speaker: CU GERMAN COMBAT BOOTS
dialogues.text: laces untied.. .boot pulled off...

dialogues.speaker: SOCKS
dialogues.text: removed, reveling dead bare feet...

dialogues.speaker: BASTERDS
dialogues.text: tossing the boots off a hill.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: Throwing them away from the bodies...

dialogues.speaker: DEAD GERMANS
dialogues.text: scalps removed from their heads, pink bare feet...

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ, (VO)
dialogues.text: The Basterds, took their lives, their hair, their valuables, their identity, and finally their dignity in death. True that. The sight of the dead soldiers with bare feet does rob the tableaux of a certain dignity, that is norma felt in battlefield shots.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: The dogsl He fights his frustration, then...

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BASTERDS
dialogues.text: Aldo screams to The Basterd who's guarding the two German prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Hey Hirschberg, send that kraut sarge over.

dialogues.speaker: BASTERD PFC.HIRSCHBERG
dialogues.text: KICKS Sgt.Rachtman in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: zw.

dialogues.speaker: PFC.HIRSCHBERG
dialogues.text: You! Go! Sgt.Rachtman is a little slow to respond. So Hirschberg grabs him by the hair, YANKS him to his feet, and KICKS h in the ass, sending him on his way. Most of The Bastreds sit in a circle, Indian style, with Aldo in the middle. As Sgt.Rachtman walks towards this circle of Basterds, A OFF SCREEN LITERARY NARRATOR (not Pvt.Butz) speaks over the SOUNDTRACK in ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: Sgt.Werner Rachtman has seen many interrogations since Germany decided it should rule Europe. But this is the first time he's ever been on the wrong end of the exchange. It's always been his belief, only a weakling, in mind, body, and spirt complies with the enemy under threat of consequence. As Werner watched men cry like women, pleadingly offer their knowledge, in exchange for their worthless lives, he made a vow to himself. If his role is to die in this conflict. When they put him under the earth, his dignity would be buried with him. For in the other world, the gods only respect the ones they test first. Well Sgt, this is your test. And the gods are watching. The captured German Sgt, enters the circle of Basterds, stands straight before the sitting southern Lieutenant, a salutes his captor.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: (ENGLISH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sgt.Werner Rachtman. Aldo returns the salute, looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Lt.Aldo Raine, pleased to meet cha. You know what sit down means Werner?

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Then sit down.
The German Sgt does.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Hows your English Werner? Cause if need be, we gotta a couple fellas can translate. Aldo points at one of The Basterds in the circle, CPL.WILHELM WICKI.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Wicki there, a Austrian Jew, got the fuck outta Saltzberg, while the gettin was good. Became American, got drafted, and came back to give y'all what for. Then Aldo points to another Basterd. A big scary looking Basterd, in a German Sgt's uniform, named, SGT.HUGO STIGL

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: And another one over there, you might be familiar with, Sgt.Hugo Stiglitz. Heard of 'em. The two German Sgt's look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: Everybody in the German army's heard of Hugo Stiglitz. The Basterds laugh, a couple pat Hugo on the back. The NARRATOR comes back on the SOUNDTRACK.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: The reason for Hugo Stiglitz's celebrity among German soldiers is simple. WE SEE A PHOTO OF HUGO on the front page of the Nazi vers of Stars and Stripes (the military newspaper).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: As a German enlisted man, he killed thirteen Gestapo officers, mostly Majors.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: Instead of putting him up against a wall, the High Command decided to send him back to Berlin, to be made a example of. Hugo in chains, being put in a lone troop truck, part of prison convoy, enroute to Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: Needless to say, once The Basterds heard about him, he never got there.

dialogues.speaker: EXT- FRENCH COUNTRYSIDE
dialogues.text: The Basterds AMBUSH the prison convoy, killing everybody. They walk to the back of the troop truck, inside Hugo in chains, stares back at them.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Sgt.Hugo Stiglitz? Hugo nods.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: I'm Lt.Aldo Raine, and these are The Basterds. Ever heard of us? Hugo nods his head, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: We just wanna say, we're a big fan of your work. When it comes to killin Nazi's, I think you show great talent, and I pride myself on havin a eye for that kind of talent. But your status as a Nazi killer, is still amateur. We all came here to see, if you wanna go pro? BACK TO THEBASTERD CIRCLE.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Now Werner, I'm gonna assume you know who we are?

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: Aldo the Apache. The circle of Basterds giggle.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Well Werner, if you heard of us, you probably heard, we ain't in the prisoner takin business. We in the killin Nazi business. And cousin, business is boomin. The Basterds laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: Now that leaves two ways we can play this out. Either kill ya, or let ya go. Now weather or not you gonna leave this circle alive, depends entirely on you. Aldo takes out a map of the area, and lays it out in fron of his prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Up the road a piece, there's a orchard. 'sides you, we know there's another kraut patrol fuckin around here somewhere. Now if that patrol were to have any crackshots, that orchard, would be a goddamn snipers delight. Now if you ever wanna eat a sauerkraut sandwich again, you gotta show me on this map, where they are, you gotta tell me how many they are, and you gotta tell me, what kinda artillery they carrying with 'em?

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: You can't expect me to divulge information that would put German lives in danger?

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: well, Werner that's where your wrong. Because that's exactly what I expect. I need to know about Germans hidin in trees? And you need to tell me? And you need to tell me, right now? Now take your finger, and point out on this map, where this partys bein held, how manys comin, and what they brought to play with? Werner site, head held high, back straight, chin up, ever inch the German hero facing death.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.WERNER
dialogues.text: F I respectfully refuse, sir. Aldo jerks his thumb behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: You see that ole boy battin rocks? WE RACK FOCUS to a one of The Basterds not in the circle. He's wearing a wife beater, and power hitting stones with a baseball bat. Werners eyes go to the ballplayer.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: That's Sgt.Donny Donowitz. But you might know him better by his nickname, The Bear Jew. Now if you heard of Aldo the Apache, you gotta heard about The Bear Jew?

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: I heard.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: What did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: He beats German soldiers with a club.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: He bashes their brains in with a baseball bat, what he does.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: back to us, still haven't seen his face. He Babe Ruths a rock soaring into the atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: Now Werner, I'm gonna ask you one last-goddamn-time, and if you still, "respectfully refuse", I'm callin The Bear Jew over here, and he's gonna take that big bat of his, and he's gonna beat your ass to death with it. Now take your wennersitnitzel lickin finger, and point out on this map what I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.RACHTMAN
dialogues.text: Fuck you and your jew dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t v. Instead of getting mad, The Basterds burst out LAUGHING. I k Aldo says to Werner, with a giggle in his voice;

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Actually Werner, we're all tickled ya said that. Frankly, watchin Donny beat Nazi's,to death, is the closest we ever get to goin to the movies. (YELLING)

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: he turns to CAMERA, and yells;

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Got a German here wants to die for country. Oblige him.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONNY DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: Bat over his shoulder, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Donny, cutting heads, in his pop's barber shop, in Bostin

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: .ya got the goddamn fuckin Germans, declaring open season on Jews in Europe, and I'm suppose to fly to the fuckin Philippines, and fight a bunch of fuckin Japs - not me pal. If we just go in this against the Japs, the whole U.S.of fuckin A can go take a running jump at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD
dialogues.text: You know they got a word for what your sayin Donny, it's called treason.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Hey, stick your treason up your poop hole. If I'm gonna kill my fellow man in the name of liberty, that fellow man, will be German.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MR.GOOROWITZ'S sporting goods shop in Donny's Jewish Bost neighbourhood. Donny walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Hello Donny, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Ah, just dandy, Mr.Goorowitz.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Your mother, your father - everything good there?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: There just fine. I'm shippin off next week. The store proprietor, extends his hand to the young man.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Good for you son. Kill one of those Nazi basterds for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: That's the idea, Mr.Goorowitz.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: What can I do you for, Donny?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I need a baseball bat. The store owner leads him to a basket with eight bats ini Donny starts going through them without saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: You gettin your little brother a present before you ship out? Donny, concentrating on the bats, not looking up;

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: No. Donny's "no", silences the gabby Goorowitz. He seems to settle on one, feeling it's weight in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Can I try this one on for size, outside?
Extending his arm;

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: Be my guest. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MR.GOOROWITZ
dialogues.text: I'll get that, you go right ahead. The proprietor answers the phone, and gets into a conversation with his OFF SCREEN Mother. Donny walks outside, WE STAY IN STORE, but can see him clearly through the stores big picture window. However, Mr.Goorowitz instinctively, turns his back to Do to speak with his mother. Donny starts swinging the bat. It's pretty obvious he's pantomiming beating somebody to death with it. Then the he starts yelling;

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Take that ya Nazi basterd! You like fuckin with the Jews? Wanna Fuck with the Jews? The American jews are gonna FUCK with you... ..! Mr.Goorowitz, see's none of this, as he speaks to his mother. He hangs up the phone, just as Donny walks back i the store. Store owner turns to store customer.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Is this the heaviest ya got?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Donny, dressed nice, in a apartment building in his Jewis Bastin neighbourhood. He knocks on a door. A VERY OLD JEWISH WOMAN opens the door, only a little, peering out at the young man.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs.Himmelstein?

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: State your business young man.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs.Himmelstein, I'm Donny Donowitz, my father Sy Donowitz, owns the barber shop on Greeny Ave, "Sy's Barber Shop".

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: I've seen it. Do you live in the neighbourhood?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: All my life.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: Again, state your business?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: May I have a word with you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Our people in Europe. She thinks for a beat, then holds the door open for the young man.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: Come in. Would you like some tea?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Donny sits on a overstuffed sofa, holding a tea cup and saucer in his hand. Mrs.Himmelstein sits on a overstuffed chair, holding her tea, looking across at her visitor.

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: (Sipping tea) Very good.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: If you like tea. Donny chuckles at her little joke. The old woman remains stone. She wasn't joking. He places his saucer on the cof table and begins;

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs.Himmelstein, do you have any love ones over in Europe who your concerned for?

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: What compels you young man, to ask a stranger such a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Because I'm going to Europe. And I'm gonna make it right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: And just how do intend to do that, Joshua?

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: And what exactly do you intend to do with that toy?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna beat every Nazi I find to death with it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: I thought we were having tea together?

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: And in this pursuit, how is it that I can be of service?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: I'm going through the neighbourhood. If you have any love ones in Europe, who's safety you fear for, I'd like you to write their name on my bat.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BASTERDS
dialogues.text: Donny takes a long walk to Werner... As WE CUT BACK and FORTH BETWEEN DONNY WALKING and WERNER WAITING, WE ALSO CUT BACK and FORTE BETWEEN DONNY and MRS.HIMMELSTEIN...

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: You must be a real BASTERD, Donny?

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: You bet your sweet ass I am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: Good. A Basterds work is never done. Specially in Germany. Donny steps up to the plate, looking down at the Nazi;

dialogues.speaker: DONNY
dialogues.text: Gimmie your papers. Werner hands Donny up his papers. Donny RIPS the identity page out, and sticks it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MRS.HIMMELSTEIN
dialogues.text: Hand me your sword Gideon. I do believe I will join you on this journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she signs the BAT, "MADELEINE"

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BASTERDS
dialogues.text: Donny BEATS Werner TO DEATH WITH THE BAT, to the cheers o The Basterds.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: watches. Hirschberg says to him;

dialogues.speaker: PFC.HIRSCHBERG
dialogues.text: About now, I'd be shittin my pants, if I was you. Aldo points a finger at Butzsr and crooks it toward him.

dialogues.speaker: PFC.HIRSCHBERG
dialogues.text: That means you, cup cake. A crying, visibly shaken, Butz site down in front of Aldo

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: You wanna live?

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Point out on this map, the German position. His arm shoots out like a rocket, and points out the positions.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: This area here.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: Maybe twelve.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: What kinda of artillery?

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: They have a machine gunn dug in here pointing north.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: How did you survived this ordel? WE SEE Pvt.Butz in The Fuhrer's room for the first time. He wears a Nazi cap, which is unusual in the presence of Fuhrer, but he seems okay with it.

dialogues.speaker: PRVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: They let me go.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Now when you report what happened here, you can't tell 'em, you told us, what you told us. They'll shoot ya. But there gonna wanna know, why you so special, we let you live? So tell 'em, we let ya live, so you could spread the word through the ranks, what's gonna happen to every Nazi we find.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: You are not to tell anybody anything! Not one word of detail! Your outfit was ambushed, and you got a away. Not one word more.

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: Yes mine Fuhrer.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Did they mark you like they did the other survivors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36ГѓВўГ‚В‚В¬Г‚Вў

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: Yes mine Fuhrer.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Remove your hat and show me.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Now say we let ya go, and say you survive the'war? When you get back home, what'eha gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: I will hug my mother like I've never hugged her before.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Well, ain't that's a real nice boy. Are you going to take off your uniform?

dialogues.speaker: PVT.BUTZ
dialogues.text: Not only shall I remove it, but I intend to burn it! The young German is telling Aldo, what he thinks, Aldo wa to hear. But the last answer didn't go down as well as he thought it would, evident by the frown on Aldo's face.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what we thought. We don't like that. You see, we like our Nazi's in uniforms. That way, you can spot 'em, just like that. (Snaps his fingers) But you take off that uniform, ain't nobody gonna know you was a Nazi. And that don't sit well with us. Aldo removes a LARGE KNIFE from a sheath on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: So I'm gonna give ya a little somethin, you can't take off.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HITLER
dialogues.text: Pvt.Butz removes his combat helmet, hair hangs in his fac his moves it aside, and WE SEE a SWASTIKA has been HAND CARVED INTO HIS FOREHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on ground, looking up at them. Aldo has just carved the swastika, and he's holding the bloody knife. All The Basterds crowd around to admire his handy work.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: You know Lieutenant, your getting pretty good at that.

dialogues.speaker: LT. ALDO
dialogues.text: You know how you get to Carnegie Hall, don't 'ch? Practice.

dialogues.speaker: "GERMAN NIGHT IN PARIS"
dialogues.text: NOTE: This whole Chapter will be filmed in French New Wav Black and White.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: We're in the auditorium of a cinema in Paris. However the CAMERA is pointed in the direction of the audience, not t screen. We start CLOSE on the projector beam, emanating f the little glass window in the back of the theatre The CAMERA continues to DOLLY back, making the Shot Wider Wider, bringing in more and more the German occupied citi of Paris, who stare at the OFF SCREEN silver screen in th We can hear the OFF SCREEN SOUNDTRACK of a Goebbels produ German omm paw paw musical movie being projected. The Shot continues to pull further and further back, and German dialogue continues to fill the auditorium... TILL... .The DOLLY SHOT LANDS on a CLOSE UP of Shosanna,. watchin movie.

dialogues.speaker: OF SHOSANNA'S FAMILY"
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of the German musicals climax. The lights go up in the auditorium. Shosanna, dressed in a NURSES UNIFORM she swiped from somewhere, remains seated, as the rest of the PATRONS, ga their coats, and file out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Patrons exit under the cinema marquee, as someone from in SHUTS OFF the marquees lights. The MARQUEE READS in French: "GERMAN NIGHT BRIDGET VON HAMMERSMARK in MADCAP IN MEXICO

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A French Black Man, who we will learn later is named MARC is the cinema's projectionist. We see him for a moment, t the film reels off the projector, and placing them on rew

dialogues.speaker: CU SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: still sitting in her seat. Except for her, the auditorium empty. The owner of the Cinema, a attractive looking French woma who we will later know as MADAME MIMIEUX, appears in one of the cinema's opera box balconies. Looking down from her perch at the young girl, sitting in the empty cinema. The DIALOGUE will be spoken in FRENCH, and SUBTITLED into ENGLISH.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: So young woman, since it's beyond obvious we're closed for the evening. I must assume you want something. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: May I sleep here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: So I gather your not a nurse?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: But your a bright little thing, that's clever disguise. Where is your family?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Murdered.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: So your a war orphan?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: We were from Nancy. The Bosch found us

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Is this a sad story?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Sad stories bore me. These days everyone in Paris has one. I haven't bore you with mine, don't bore me with yours.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: You can run the machines?

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: What machines? Using her hands to pantomime the rotating film reels on a projector, she says;

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: The machines that show the film?

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: The projectors? Yes, I own a cinema, of course I can operate them.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I know, I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: CU SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: eyes creeping up the stairway in the projection booth, watching...

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: expertly working the projectors...

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Teach me. Teach me to run the machines, that show the film. It's only you and the negro. I know you could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: I know at least six people who've been put up against a wall, and machine gunned for sheltering enemies of the state. I have no intention of being unlucky number seven. How long have you been in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: A week, and a few days.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: How have you survived the curfew without capture?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I sleep on rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Again, I'm forced to admit, clever girl. How is it?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Cold.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Respectfully, no you can't.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: So you can't operate a 35mm film projector, you want me teach you, in order to work here, in order to use my cinema, as a hole to hide in, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Whats your name?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Shosanna.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: I'm Madame Mimieux. You may call me Madame. This is a cinema. Not a home for wayward war orphans. Having said that, what you say is true. If you were truly exceptional, I could find use for you. So Shosanna, are you truly exceptional?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: I will be the judge of that.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: Which shows a lovely PENCIL SKETCH of the CITY OF PARIS, complete with Eiffel Tower.

dialogues.speaker: THEN...
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK, and we see we're not looking at a CARD at all, but a CALENDER stuck on the wall of the Litt Cinema's Projection Booth. Before we leave it, WE SEE the Month is JUNE. ..The CAMERA finds, the THREE YEARS OLDER SHOSANNA, worki as the PROJECTIONIST. It would appear, that Shosanna pass Madame Mimieux's exceptional test. A lyrical Morriconie-like tune PLAYS on the SOUNDTRACK, t will be "Shosanna's Theme". A Little Bell, begins RINGING, on one of the projectors, alerting Shosanna it's time for a REEL CHANGE. Shosanna stands at the projector, watching the old German she's projecting, waiting for the1st REEL CHANGE MARK...

dialogues.speaker: SILVER SCREEN
dialogues.text: of the little cinema. On Screen LENI REFENSHTAL lies horizontal as a ice sickle drips on her head in the old German film, "The White Hell Of Piza Palu", The 1st REEL CHANGE MARK POPS ON in the upper right hand corner of the FRAME...(That tells the projectionist to get ready).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the FILM REEL on the lst PROJECTOR rolls out, Shosanna stands ready, waiting by the 2nd PROJECTOR... WHEN...

dialogues.speaker: SILVER SCREEN
dialogues.text: the 2nd REEL CHANGE MARK POPS ON in the same place(That's one).

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: THROWS the lever on the 2nd PROJECTOR, switching the film projector 1# to projector 2#, executing a perfect REEL CH As Shosanna's Theme plays on the Soundtrack, we watch viv MONTAGE, her go through her daily chores. Carry heavy fil up the stairs, empty the rat traps, ect,ect...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The MARQUEE READS in French: "GERMAN NIGHT LENI REFENSHTAL in PABST WHITE HELL OF PIZA Shosanna emerges from the cinema carrying two buckets of LETTERS (for the marquee), and a tall ladder. Her chore h obviously, is to change the show on the marquee. The LITERARY NARRATOR comes on the Soundtrack in ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (VO)
dialogues.text: To operate a cinema in Paris during the occupation, one had two choices. Ether you could show new German propaganda films, produced under the watchful eye of Joseph Goebbels. Or... .you could have a German night in your weekly schedule, and show allowed German classic films. Their German night was Thursday. Shosanna, by herself, perched up high on the ladder, chan the letters on the marquee. A YOUNG GERMAN SOLDIER(about the same age as Shosanna), w out of the cinema. He sees the ladder with the young Fren girl on top, and walks over. They speak FRENCH, SUBTITLED into ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: What starts tomorrow? Shosanna looks down, seeing the young German Solder smili at her from below.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: A Max Linder festival.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Ummmm, I always preferred Linder to Chaplin. Except Linder never made a film as good as "The Rid". The chase climax of "The Kid", superb. Shosanna continues working, not adding to the conversatio

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: I suppose now you could use a "M" a "A" and a "X"?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: No need, I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous, it's my pleasure. He hands the French damsel the letters spelling MAX.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Merci.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: I adore your cinema very much.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Merci. She busies herself with the marquee letters...

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: How does a young girl, such as yourself, own a cinema? Do to his uniform, and Shosanna's situation, all his effo at trying to make small talk, strikes the young Jewess in hiding as a Gestapo interrogation.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: My aunt left it to me.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Lucky girl. Shosanna makes no reply back.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Merci for hoisting a German night.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I don't have a choice, but your welcome.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Do you chose the German films yourself?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Then my merci stands. I love the Refensthal mountain films, especially, "Pizu Palu". It's nice to see a French girl who's a admirer of Refensthal.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: "Admire", would not be the adjective I would use to describe my feelings towards Fraulein Refensthal.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: But you do admire the director. Pabst, don't you? That's why you included his name on the marquee. She climbs down from the ladder and faces the German Private.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I'm French. We respect directors in our country.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Apparently even Germans.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Even Germans. Merci for assistance, Private. Adieu. She turns to go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Your not finished?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I'll finish in the morning. She opens the door to go inside.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: May I ask your name?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: You wish to see my papers? She hands him her excellently forged papers. That's obviously not what he meant, but he takes them any to read her name.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Emmanuelle Mimieux. That's a very pretty name.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Merci. Are you finished with my papers? He hands them back.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle. My name is Fredrick Zoller. She gives no response.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure chatting with a fellow cinema lover. Sweet dreams, Mademoiselle. He gives her a little salute, and walks into the black of curfew imposed night. She looks after him. She didn't show it, but he kinda got her. After all, for any true cinema lover, it's hard to h anybody who, CINEMA MON AMOUR.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Shosanna stands on the roof of her cinema, late at night, lighting up a cigarette. As she takes her first big drag, she remembers a voice.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH ON
dialogues.text: MADAME MIMIEUX, the younger Shosanna, and the black projectionist Marcel, in the projection booth. Shosanna lights up a cigarette, and Madame Mimieux SLAPS her face HARD, knocking the cigarette out of her mouth. Marcel quickly STAMPS it out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If-7.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: if I ever see you light up a cigarette in my cinema again, I'll turn you into the Nazi's, do you understand? Shosanna is shocked by this statement.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: And for bringing a open flame in my cinema, you deserve far worse then a Nazi jewish boxcar. With your thick head, what do you think the highest priority of a cinema manager is? Keeping this fucking place from burning down to the ground, that's what! In my collection, I have over 350, 35mm, nitrate film prints, which are not only immensely flammable, but highly unstable. And should they catch fire, they burn three times faster then paper. If that happens.. .POOF...all gone, cinema no more, every body burned alive. If I ever see you with a open flame in my cinema again, I won't turn you into the Nazi's I'll kill you myself. And the fucking Germans will give me a curfew pass. Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Out, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: Do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Out, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME MIMIEUX
dialogues.text: You damn well better.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ROOF
dialogues.text: Shosanna exhales cigarette smoke. Marcel comes onto the roof.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Are you well?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Even on the roof I can't smoke a cigarette without hearing Madames voice yelling at me. That's why I do it. To hear Madames voice again.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: We both miss her.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I know. I'm fine, darling. I'll be to bed soon. Marcel goes back inside, Shosanna smokes.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Shosanna sits in the back of a French bistro, reading a book, "The Saint in New York" by Leslie Charteris, drinki wine. When the young German Private from the other day, FREDRICK ZOLLER, walks in. He gets a beer, then notices t French girl sitting in the back. He smiles, and heads ove to her. "Oh no, not this guy again", she thinks. Again they speak in FRENCH SUBTITLED into ENGLISH;

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: May I join you?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Look Fredrick -

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: (SMILING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - You remember my name?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Yes....Look, you seem a pleasant enough fellow -

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: - Merci.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Your welcome. - regardless, I want you to stop pestering me.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I apologize mademoiselle, I wasn't trying to be a pest. I was simply trying to be friendly.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: I don't wish to be your friend.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Don't act like a infant. You know why.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I'm more then just a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Not to me. If you are so desperate for a French girlfriend, I suggest you try Vichy? Just then TWO OTHER GERMAN SOLDIERS come over, obviously very impressed with Fredrick. They make a fuss over him i UNSUBTITLED GERMAN, which nether Shosanna, or the non Ger speaking members of the movies audience, can understand. He signs autographs for them, shakes their hands, and the go on their way. Shosanna's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I thought I was just a uniform?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Your not just a German soldier, are you somebodies son?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Most German soldiers are somebodies son.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but your not just somebody. What are you, Hitlers nephew? He leans in across the table, she leans in too, and he sa

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: No not really, I'm just teasing you. She leans back annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Then what is it? What are you, a German movie star?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (Pfuit), what does that mean, "not exactly". I asked if you were a movie star, the answer to that question, is yes or no. Fredrick laughs at that line.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICR
dialogues.text: When you said that just now, you reminded me of my sister. This catches young Shosanna off guard.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICR
dialogues.text: I come from a home of six sisters. We run a family operated cinema in Munich. Seeing you run around your cinema, reminds me of them. Especially my sister Helga. She raised me, when our father wasn't up to the job. I admire her very much. You'd like her, she doesn't wear a German uniform.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: You were raised by Helga?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: All my sisters, I'm the baby, but Helga was the bossiest.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: And your mother and father?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: My mother died. And my father was a loser. My fathers moto; "If at first you don't succeed, quit". The day he left, good riddance. My sisters are all I need. It's why I like your cinema. It makes me feel both closer to them, and a little homesick at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: is your cinema still operatiing?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICR
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: What's it called?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: The Kino Haus.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: How has it done durring the war?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Actually, in Germany, cinema attendance is up.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: No doubt, you don't have to operate under a curfew.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: How often do you fill your house?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (Pfuit), not since before the war.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: So if you had one big engagement, that would help you out?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Of course, but that's not likely to happen. TWO MORE GERMAN SOLDIERS and their TWO FRENCH DATES appro the table. They ask for Fredricks autograph, he signs it them. One of the French Girls says in FRENCH, how excitin it is to meet a real live German war hero. Shosanna hears it. They leave. So that's it, she thinks.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: So your a war hero? Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Everybody knows that, I liked you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: What did you do? He takes a sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I've shot the most enemy soldiers in world war two...so far. You bet your sweet ass that got her attention.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I was alone in a bell tower in a walled off city in Russia. It was myself, and a thousand rounds of ammo, in a bird's nest, against three hundred Soviet soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: What's a bird's nest?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: A bird's nest is what a sniper would call a bell tower. It's a high structure, offering a three hundred and sixty degree view. Very advantageous for marksmen.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: How many Russian's did you kill?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Sixty-eight. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day. A hundred and fifty the second day. Thirty-two, the third day. On the forth day, they exited the city. Naturally my war story received alot of attention in Germany, that's why they all recognize me. They call me the German Sgt.York.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll make a film about your exploits.

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Well, that's just what Joseph Goebbels thought. So he did. It's called "Nation's Pride", and guess what, they wanted me to play myself, so I did. They have posters for it in kiosks all over Paris. That's another reason for all the attention.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: "Nation's Pride" is about you? "Nation's Pride" is starring you?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: I know, comical, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Not so comical. So what are you doing in Paris, enjoying a rest?

dialogues.speaker: FREDRICK
dialogues.text: Hardly. I've been doing publicity, having my picture taken with different German luminaries, visiting troops, that sort of thing. Goebbels wants the film to premier in Paris, so I've been helping them in the planning. Joseph is very keen on this film. He's telling anybody who will listen, when "Nation's Pride" is released, I'll be the German Van Johnson. Shosanna, wasn't falling for the young German, by any str However his exploits, as well as his charming manner, can help but impress. But his referring to Goebbels as "Josep like their friends, is all she needed to get on the right of things. This young man is trouble with a capital "T", she needs to stay far fucking away from him. She abruptly rises, and says;

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Well, good luck with your premier Private. I hope all goes well for Joseph and yourself. Au revoir. And with that, she disappears. Leaving the perplexed priv alone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It's the next day. Shosanna and Marcel are changing the letters on the marqu Marcel excuses himself to visit the toilet. $hosanna is alone outside the little cinema, perched up o ladder. WHEN... .A BLACK NAZI SEDAN pulls up in front of the little cinem A GERMAN MAJOR in a black Gestapo uniform steps out of th of the sedan. The DRIVER, a German Private, steps out as well. Yelling to the young girl up high on the ladder; Both GERMAN and FRENCH will be SUBTITLED into ENGLISH.

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle Nimieux?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui? Telling his Driver in German to ask her in French;

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: Ask her if this is her cinema? in French The Driver asks Shosanna;

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: is this your cinema?

dialogues.speaker: GESTAPO MAJOR
dialogues.text: Tell her to come down.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Come down please. She climbs down the ladder. The Driver opens the back door of the sedan, indicating f to get in.

dialogues.text: Like I said, what the fuck are we suppose to do?

dialogues.text: Well, I need to speak with you about that.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: About these Hun swine, commandeering our cinema.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: What about it? She slowly walks up the stairs to Marcel. She makes him p his legs, and sits on the lower step, between his legs. H back up against his chest, his arms around her shoulders. Shosanna has only known this type of intimacy with Marcel

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Well, when I was watching the bosch (Said in

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH
dialogues.text: Capra-corn abomination, (Back to

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH
dialogues.text: I got a idea.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: I'm confused, what are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Filling the cinema with Nazi's and their whores, and burning it down to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about that, your talking about that.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: No, we're talking about that, right now. If we can keep this place from burning down by ourselves, we can burn it down by ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Shosanna -

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: No, Marcel, just for sake of argument, if we wanted to burn down the cinema, for any number of reasons, you and I could physically accomplish that, no?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Oui Shosanna, we could do that.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: And with Madame Mimieux's 350 nitrate film print collection, we wouldn't even need explosives, would we?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: You mean we wouldn't need any more explosives?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Oui, that's exactly what I mean. She begins kissing his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to burn down the cinema on Nazi night. One of his fingers probes her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I'm going to burn down the cinema, which I am, we both know, your not going to let me do it by myself. The back of her head presses up hard against him, as his both caresses, and grips her lovely neck.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you love me. And I love you. And your the only person on this earth I can trust. She then TWISTS around, so she's straddling him. They are face to face.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: (CON'T)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not all we're going to do. Does the filmmaking equipment it the attic still work? I know the film camera does. How about the sound recorder?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Quite well, actually. I recorded a new guitarist I met in a cafe last week. It works superb. Why do we need filmmaking equipment?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Because Marcel, my sweet, we're going to make a film. Just for the Nazi's.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A young MILITARY ATTACHE, opens the sliding double doors that serve as a entrance to the room.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY ATTACHE
dialogues.text: Right this way, Lieutenant. A snappy handsome British Lieutenant in dress browns, ste the room. This officer, who has been mixing it up with the Gerrys since the late thirties, is named LT.ARCHIE HI A young George Sanders type(The Saint and Private affairs Bel Ami, years). Upon entering the room, Lt.Hicox is gobsmacked. Standing before him is legendary military mastermind, GENERAL ED FENECH, a older George Sanders type (Village o Dammed). But in the back of the room, sitting behind a piano, smoking his ever present cigar, is the unmistakable bulk of WINSTON CHURCHELL.

dialogues.speaker: LT. HICOX
dialogues.text: Lt. Archie Hicox, reporting sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEN FENECH
dialogues.text: (Salutes back) General Ed Fenech, at ease Hicox. Drink? Hicox's eye's go to the formidable bulldog behind the pia who's scrutinizing him behind his cigar. However the man the cigar makes no gesture, and the General, makes no acknowledgment of the three hundred pound gorilla in the Which Lt.Hicox knows enough to mean, if Churchell isn't introduced, he ain't there.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: if you offered me a scotch and plane water, I could drink a scotch and plain water.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: That a boy, Lieutenant. Make it yourself, like a good chap, will you? Bars in the globe. Hicox heads over to the bar globe.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Something for yourself, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Whiskey straight. No junk in it. The Lieutenant moves over to the Columbus-style globe bar busies himself mixing spirits, playing bartender chappy. Fenech, eyeing the Lieutenant's file.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: It says here you've run three undercover commando operations in Germany, and German occupied territories? Frankfaurt, Holland, and Norway to be exact? Back to them, mixing drinks, he says;

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Extraordinary people, the Norwegian's.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: It says here you speak German fluently?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Like a Katzenjammer Kid.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: And your occupation before the war? His back still to us, as he bartends...

dialogues.speaker: LT. H I COX
dialogues.text: I'm a film critic.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: List your accomplishments?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Well sir, such as they are, I write reviews and articles, for a publication called; "Films and Filmmakers". As well as our sister publication.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: What's that called?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: "Flickers Bi-Monthly". And I've had two books published.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Impressive. Don't be modest Lieutenant, what are their titles?

dialogues.speaker: LT. HI COX
dialogues.text: The first book was called; "Art Of The Eye's, The Heart, and The Mind:A Study of German Cinema in the Twenties". And the second one was called; ... He turns around with his whiskey and plain water, and the Generals whiskey no junk. He finishes what he was saying, he walks toward the General, handing him his drink.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: "Twenty-Four Frame Da Vinci". It's a subtexual film criticism study of the work of German director G.W. Pabst.

dialogues.speaker: LT. HI COX
dialogues.text: What should we drink to, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: (Thinking, for a moment) Down with Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: All the way down, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with German cinema under the Third Reich?

dialogues.speaker: LT. HI COX
dialogues.text: Yes. Obviously I haven't seen any of the films made in the last three years, but I am familiar with it.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Explain it to me.?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Pardon sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: This little escapade of ours, requires a knowledge of the German film industry under the Third Reich. Explain to me UFA, under Goebbels?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Goebbels considers the films he's making to be the beginning of a new era in German cinema. A alternative to what he considers the Jewish German intellectual cinema of the twenties. And the Jewish controlled dogma of Hollywood. SUDDENLY... Bellowing from the back of the room;

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHELL
dialogues.text: How's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: LT. H I COX
dialogues.text: Frightfully sorry sir, once again?

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHELL
dialogues.text: You say he wants to take on the Jews at their own game? Compared to say .Louis B.Mayer...how's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Quite well, actually. Since Goebbels has taken over, film attendance has steadily risen in Germany over the last eight years. But Louis B.Mayer wouldn't be Goebbels proper opposite number. I believe Goebbels see's himself closer to David O.Selznick. Gen.Fenech looks to the Prime Minister. With a puff of cigar smoke, Churchell says;

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHELL
dialogues.text: Brief him.

dialogues.speaker: GEM.FENECH
dialogues.text: Lt.Bicox, at this point in time I'd like to brief you on, Operation Kino. Three days from now, Joseph Goebbels is throwing a gala premier of one of his new movies in Paris -

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: - What film sir? The General has to resort to peeking at his file.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: The motion pictures called; "Nation's Pride".

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean the film about Private Zoller?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: We don't have any intelligence, on exactly, what the film that night will be about.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: But it's called "Nation's Pride"?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: I can tell you what it's about, it's about Private Fredrick Zoller. He's the German Sgt.York. Fenech can't help suppress a smile, they have the right m

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: In attendance at this joyous Germatic occasion, will be Goebbels, Gerring, Boorman, and most of the German High command, including all high ranking officers of both The S.S., and, The Gestapo. As well as luminaries of the Nazi propaganda film industry.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: The master race at play, aye?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Basically, we have all our rotten eggs in one basket. The objective of Operation Kino.... Blow up the basket.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: (Reciting a a poem) "...and like the snows of yesteryear, gone from this earth". Jolly good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: An American Secret Service outfit, that lives deep behind enemy lines, will be your assist. The Germans call them; "The Basterds".

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: "The Basterds", never heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Whole point of the secret service, old boy, you not hearing of them. But the Gerrys have heard of them, because these yanks have been them the devil. Their leader is a chap named Lt.Aldo Raine. The Germans call him, "Aldo the Apache".

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Why do they call him that?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Best guess, is because he removes the scalps of the Nazi dead.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Scalps, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: The hair. He runs his finger along his hairline.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: Like a red Injun.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Rather gruesome sounding little Dicky bird, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: No doubt the whole lot, a bunch a nutters. But you've heard the expression, "It takes a thief".

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Indeed. General Fenech continues on with his exposition, moving o to a military map.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: You'll be dropped into France, about twenty four kilometers outside of Paris. The Basterds will be waiting for you. First thing, you go to a little village called, "Nadine". (He points it out on the map) Apparently the Gerrys never go there. In Nadine, there's a tavern, called, "La Louisiane", you'll rendez-vous with our double agent, and she'll take it from there. She's the one who's going to get you in the premiere. It will be you, her, and two German born members of the Basterds. She's also made all the other arrangements your going to need.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: How will I know her?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: I suspect that won't be too much trouble for you. Your contact is Bridget Von Hammersmark.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Bridget Von Hammersmark? The German movie star is working for England?

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: For the last two years now. one could even say Operation Kino was her brainchild. In the back of the room the bulldog barks;

dialogues.speaker: CHURCHELL
dialogues.text: Extraordinary women.

dialogues.speaker: LT.BICOX
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: GEN.FENECH
dialogues.text: You'll go to the premiere as her escort, lucky devil. She'll also have the premiere tickets for the other two. Got the gist?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: I think so, sir. Paris when it sizzles. The three British bulldogs laugh.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Shosanna and Marcel are on the rooftop of their cinema, literally, making a movie. Marcel is behind a old (even then) BOLEX 35MM MOVIE CAMER positioned low looking up. Shosanna, the camera subject, stands on boxes looking dow into it. A old timey MICROPHONE is positioned out of frame. As they always do, and always will, they speak FRENCH SUBTITLED into you know what.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: We need a sync mark.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: What is a sync mark?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: A action and noise put together, So we can sync up the picture and sound.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: How do we do that?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Clap your hands. She does.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: In frame imbecile. She claps her hands in front of her face.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Ready? Shosanna takes a deep breath, then;

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Action. WE CUT BEFORE SHE SPEAKS TO...

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY, ON THE STAIRS, TALKING ABOUT BURNING DOWN THE CINE
dialogues.text: Big diffrence this time, it's in COLOR.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: But how do we get it developed? Only a suicidal idiot like us would develop that footage. How do we get a35mm print with a soundtrack?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Do you know one person who can do both things?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Of course Gaspar, very nice man, took care of all the experimental filmmakers. But nobody in their right mind would strike a print of what your talking about. If the Nazi's found out, their life wouldn't be worth this. He snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: In a wolf fight, you ether eat the wolf, or the wolf eats you. If we're going to obliterate the Nazi's, we have to use their tactics.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: We find somebody who can develop and process a35mm print. And we make them do it, or we kill them. Once we tell them what we want to do, if they refuse, we have to kill them anyway, or they'll turn us in.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Like that. Snaps her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A old mom and pop film processing lab circa the Thirties. Late late at night. GASPAR, the fatherly figure of all the experimental Frenc filmmakers in the decade before German rule, takes a SAVA BEATING at the hands of his friend Marcel. Shosanna watches, pitiless.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Bring that fucker over here! Put his head down on that table. Marcel, holds his arm behind him, as he forces his head f against the table top. Shosanna brings a HATCHET DOWN DEEP into the table, just his face.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: You ether do what the fuck we tell you to, or I'll bury this axe in your collaborating skull.

dialogues.speaker: GASPAR
dialogues.text: I'm not a collaborator!

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Then prove it! Or does your manhood go no deeper, then standing to piss? Marcel, does his wife, and children know you?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Then after we kill this dog for Germans, we'll go and silence them. She lifts up the hatchet, raises it high...

dialogues.speaker: SHOSANNA
dialogues.text: Prepare to die, collaborator fucker!

dialogues.speaker: GASPAR
dialogues.text: hands the couple a SMALL SILVER CAN OF 35mm FILM. Outside the shop window, it's morning.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE SEE the five heavy silver film cans of Fredrick Zoller life story "Nations Pride"(clearly marked) on the floor o the projection booth. The can for REEL 4is open and empty. Shosanna's at the editing bench, REEL 4, is up on the rewinds... Shosanna SPLICES her and Marcels footage into REEL 4 of Fredricks film. Rewinds it, puts it back in the can, and puts a piece of RED TAPE on REEL 4 CAN. She walks out of the booth, turning off the lights behind her, PLUNGING THE SCREEN INTO DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: We see a small basement tavern, with a old rustic sign ou front that reads, "La Louisiane".

dialogues.speaker: A SUBTITLE APPEARS
dialogues.text: "The Village of

dialogues.speaker: NADINE, FRANCE"
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT LT.HICOX and LT.ALDO RAINE Aldo is dressed like a French civilian. Hicox is dressed German grey S.S. Cap't uniform. They look out of a window apartment, in the village of Nadine, overlooking the tave

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: You didn't say the goddamn rendez-vous was in a fuckin basement.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: You said it was in a tavern?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: it is a tavern.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Yeah, in a basement. You know, fightin in a basement offers a lot of difficulties, number one being, your fighting in a basement. Wilhelm Wicki, joins the SHOT, dressed in a German S.S. Lieutenant uniform.

dialogues.speaker: WICKI
dialogues.text: What if we go in there, and she's not even there?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: We wait. Don't worry, she's a British spy, she'll make the rendez-vous. WE SEE the other Basterds, dressed in French civilian clo are in the room as well, they are, Donowitz, Hirschberg, and Utivich. And in the back of the room, dressed in the uniform of a S.S. Lieutenant, Hugo Stiglitz sits off by h sharpening his S.S. DAGGER on his leather belt looped aro boot. Anybody not in the scene from the Basterds opening chapter, is dead. Lt.Hicox watches Stiglitz off by himself on the other sid the room, SHARPENS his dagger menacingly. .Stiglitz is fucking werid... Lt.Hicox approaches Stiglitz...

dialogues.speaker: LT.NICOX
dialogues.text: Stiglitz, right?

dialogues.speaker: STIGLITZ
dialogues.text: That's right, sir. He continues bringing the blades edge, up, then, down on leather strap.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: I hear your pretty good with that? Meaning the blade. Stiglitz doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: You know, we're not looking for trouble, right now. We're simply making contact with our agent. Should be uneventful. However, on the off chance I'm wrong, and things prove eventful. I need to know, we can all remain calm.
The renegade Gerry Sergeant, stops his blades progress, a looks up at the limy Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: STIGLITZ
dialogues.text: I don't look calm to you?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Well, now you put it like that, I guess you do. He turns his attention back to his blade. Hicox moves over to Aldo, and asks him privately;

dialogues.speaker: LT. HI COX
dialogues.text: This Gerry of yours, Stiglitz? Not exactly the loquacious type, is he? Aldo just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Is that the kinds man you need, the loquacious type?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Fair point, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: So y'all git in trouble in there, what are we suppose to do? Make bets on how it all comes out?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: If we get into trouble, we can handle it. But if trouble does happen, we need you to make damn sure no Germans, or French, for matter, escape from that basement. If Frau Von Hammersmark's cover is compromised, the mission is kaput.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: Speaking of Frau Von Hammersmark, who's idea was it for the death trap redez-vous?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: She chose the spot.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: Well isn't that just dandy?

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Look, she's not a military strategist. She's just a actress.

dialogues.speaker: LT.ALDO
dialogues.text: Ya don't got to be Stonewall Jackson to know you don't want to fight in a basement.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: She wasn't picking a place to fight. She was picking a place, isolated, and without germans.

dialogues.speaker: PFC.HIRSCHBERG
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, I hate to be contrary, but I got me a Nazi pissin on Louisianna two-o'clock. They move to the window, and sure enough, ONE LONE NAZI PRIVATE, relieves himself against the side wall. Lt.Bicox, this was definitely, not the plan.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: Shit. Sgt.Donowitz chides him;

dialogues.speaker: SGT.DONOWITZ
dialogues.text: So what do you think your fraulein Von Hammer -

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: - Obviously, I don't know,Sgt. The British officer watches the German soldier, who's not suppose to be there. When Hugo Stiglitz joins him at the window. Stiglitz looks down at the urinating Nazi, S.S. d in hand.

dialogues.speaker: STIGLITZ
dialogues.text: If we're going, let's go. He sheaths the dagger.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The GERMAN PISSING PRIVATE, sloppily finishes his task. Craming his noodle back in his pants, he descends the sta that lead him back into the basement tavern. We Follow hi

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: .Inside the basement tavern, La Louisiane. it has a very hanging basement ceiling. A old looking wood bar off to t right. And the only other space in the little tavern, is up by two large(at least in here) tables, which take up b half's of the room. And despite rumors to the contrary, o the two tables, is completely filled with drunken celebra Nazi enlisted men, of which our urinating friend is one o five.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE NAZI'S
dialogues.text: ONE GERMAN MASTER SGT, ONE FEMALE GERMAN SGT (a powerfull stocky type), and THREE MALE GERMAN PRIVATES. The Five Nazi's are sitting around the table, drinking, a playing a very fun game with none other then the fraulein the hour, UFA diva, BRIDGET VON HAMMERSMARK. Dressed to t nines in a chic Forties style women's suit, complete with fedora. The game their playing consists of each player ha a card with the name of a famous person, real or imaginar stuck to their forehead. The player doesn't know what nam on their forehead. So they ask the others questions to fi out who they are. The Five Germans, five cards read; MASTER SGT #1(POLA NEG

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN PRIVATE
dialogues.text: (WINNETOU). And Bridget Von Hammersmark, who wears her ca the brim of her fedora, has GENGHIS KHAN. It's German#5 (WINNETOU) turn to ask questions. The DIALOGUE will be in GERMAN, and SUBTITLED into ENGLIS Also, while some dialogue will be written for the German Soldiers, it will be mostly made up from the exuberance of their game playing, and celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: .okay, I'm not German. Am I American? The whole table bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SGT/BEETHOVEN
dialogues.text: Yes you arel

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR WALLACE
dialogues.text: Well, not really.

dialogues.speaker: SGT.POLA NEGRI
dialogues.text: What do you mean, not really? Of course he is.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR WALLACE
dialogues.text: Well if he's so American, how come he's never been translated into English? He's not American. He's suppose to be American, but he's not a American creation. In fact, he's something very different.

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm a fictional, literary character, from the past, I'm American, and that's controversial.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET/GENGUS
dialogues.text: No it's not controversial. The nationally of the author, has nothing to do with the nationally of the character. The Character is the character. Hamlet's not British, he's Danish. So yes, this character was born in America.

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: Well I'm glad that's settled. If I had a wife, would she be called a squaw? He's got it. The table Laughs. The TABLE

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: Is my bloodbrother, Old Shatterhand? The TABLE Yes!

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: Did Karl May write me? The TABLE Yes! In the BACKGROUND, WE SEE, our three counterfeit German Officers, Hicox, Wicki, and Stiglitz, enter the basement tavern. They obviously. see the five German soldiers, but too far away for us (the audience) to read their face. No doubt their less then happy. Fraulein Von Hammersmark see's them as well. Without getting up, she waves to them

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: Hello, my lovelies, I will join you in moments. I'm finishing up a game with my five new friends here.

dialogues.speaker: LT.HICOX
dialogues.text: No hurry, Frau Von Hammersmark. Take your time, enjoy yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: (To Winnetou) So who are you?

dialogues.speaker: WINNETOU
dialogues.text: I am WINNETOU, CHIEF of the APACHES! The table CHEERS, and APPLAUD the Apache Chief, as he tak the card off his forehead. The other Four German Soldiers drink down there beer(part the game). Bridget Von Hammersmark knock backs her champagne.

dialogues.speaker: MATA HARI
